etymologies: late Middle English (as a verb, also in the sense ‘snore’): probably imitative; compare with snore. The noun dates from the early 19th century

definitions: an explosive sound made by the sudden forcing of breath through one's nose, used to express indignation, derision, or incredulity

examples.text: he gave a snort of disgust

shortDefinitions: explosive sound made by sudden forcing of breath through one's nose

definitions: a snorting sound made by an animal, typically when excited or frightened

examples.text: she could hear the occasional snort of a pony

definitions: a quantity of an illegal drug, especially cocaine, inhaled in powdered form through the nose

examples.text: they were high on a few snorts

shortDefinitions: quantity of illegal drug inhaled in powdered form through nose

definitions: a measure of an alcoholic drink

examples.text: a bottle of rum was opened and they took a good long snort

definitions: make a sudden sound through one's nose, especially to express indignation or derision
shortDefinitions: make sudden explosive sound through one's nose

definitions: (of an animal) make a sudden explosive sound through the nose, especially when excited or frightened

examples.text: the horse came to a halt, snorting

definitions: inhale (the powdered form of an illegal drug, especially cocaine) through the nose

examples.text: Debbie had spent the evening snorting cocaine and drinking

shortDefinitions: inhale powdered form of illegal drug through nose
